Comment: You're trying to roll a dozen issues into one.  They are separate issues that are only indirectly connected.  Tariffs are not about labor laws, plastic pollution, or living wages.  You fundamentally do not understand what a tariff is.  A tariff is a tax paid by the *importing company*, in this case a US company, that they pay to the federal government.  The importing company is not going to reduce their profit margin.  Instead, what they will do is increase the amount that consumers, which is *you*, pay for the goods.    Does that hurt the importing company?  Indirectly yes, because they will sell less goods because customers cannot afford them.  Does it hurt the average American (you)?  Yes, because you now have to pay more for the same goods, and you cannot afford to buy as many things.  The importing company can try to move the sourcing of their goods to within the US, but that is also infeasible.  Not only do Americans demand higher wages (thus making the end product even **more** expensive), it takes years to establish a factory capable of producing even simple goods that Americans demand.
